title: first animals london zoo monkey smoking jacket pictures
story: Also among the fascinating pictures from  are extinct animals like the quagga — a type of zebra of which only a handful of photos exist.And Jumbo the elephant — who was later sold to the Greatest Showman P.T Barnham despite a national outcry — features too.But also among the stunning snaps are examples of creatures performing acts that would be frowned upon today.One shows elephants giving children rides around the zoo.And another monkey is seen puffing on a pipe.The  Magic Lantern slides were recently uncovered and will be auctioned next week with an estimate of £,.London Zoo was established in April  but it wasnt until  that it was opened to the public.Photographer Frederick York took the pictures — which were transferred onto glass plates and painted.They were then used to amaze the animal-loving public in lectures to those unable to travel to London to see the zoo themselves.The main attraction at the time was the iconic Jumbo the elephant who arrived in London in .He was hugely popular among animal-mad Victorians until he was sold to the Barnum  Bailey Circus in  for £,.At the time the public objected to the sale and , schoolchildren wrote to Queen Victoria begging for him not to be sold.There was a lawsuit but a court upheld the sale and Barnum took the elephant to America — earning enough in three weeks to recoup the money he spent.Mimi Connell-Lay, from David Lay Auctioneers, said: As photography goes, these are pretty early images and they are all hand-coloured, at a time when most photos were black and white.They were printed on glass plates, which were small and fragile, so although many sets would have been made most havent survived.These are well over  years old, and to have a complete set like this is very unusual.They are pretty valuable and Im sure theyd appeal to early photography enthusiasts and natural history enthusiasts.The slides will be sold at David Lay in Penzance, Cornwall, on December .

title: henry viii castle nine bedrooms five bathrooms sale
story: Grade I listed Devizes Castle in Wiltshire was owned by Englands monarchs for about  years and was visited by King John and Edward I, as well as being owned by each of Henry VIIIs wives.The original medieval castle was destroyed by Parliamentarians after the English Civil War and the current private home was created in the s.But the grand property still has lots of period features, such as turrets, stone mullioned windows, impressive fireplaces and oak floors.The castle is ided into two homes and the principal part is on the market with estate agents Savills.Devizes Castle is steeped in history and dates as far back as  when a motte-and-bailey castle was built by the Bishop of Salisbury.That castle burnt down and was rebuilt in stone during King Henry Is reign and became a popular residence for the monarchy - described as the most gorgeous in Christendom.It was later occupied by Royalist troops during the English Civil War in the s and besieged by Parliamentarian soldiers.But after the war, the castle was dismantled following a Parliamentary Order and all that remains is the original mound, the outline of the moat and traces of the foundations of the great hall.The striking existing castellated property was built  years later by the Leach family in a Victorian Gothic style.It was even used in the Second World War as an Italian POW camp.The property is spread over five storeys, with most of the accommodation on the ground, first and second floors, but it also has a cellar and two tower rooms on the third floor.It offers , sq ft of accommodation with an entrance hall, inner hall, kitchen breakfast room, family room, dining room, library, study, long gallery, drawing room, fernery, nine bedrooms and five bathrooms.The house is surrounded by beautul gardens and offers seclusion with mature trees at the front and the castles ramparts at the back.It sits on the edge of the picturesque market town of Devizes, which formed around the original castles outskirts.George Nares from Savills said: The castle is very imposing and impressive and this property is the principle part, its just the South Tower that is separate.Naturally it will appeal to a history lover, but I think it will also have to be someone quite fun.

The aircraft then came in for a second approach and landed safely.“Upon landing the aircraft was inspected and initially there was thought to be damage to the rear landing gear.Upon further inspection though it was deemed safe to fly and the aircraft departed Newcastle for Dubai  minutes later than planned.”It is not unusual for aircraft to point into the wind during times of high crosswind.

title: 999 recording girl saved mum
story: Kaitlyn Wright rang the emergency services when her mum Charlene collapsed at home and talked the operator through what was happening.She told the operator her mum was having a fit and she “needed to look after her”.When she was askedshe was alone she replied: “It’s just me. And a dog and a kitten.”Kaitlyn tried to describe to how to get to her family home in Dorchester, Dorset by telling them to go “down the big hill and up the other side”.The operator was able to trace the call and paramedics raced to their home in Askerswell.By the time paramedics got there Charlene had recovered and did not require further treatment.The -year-old mum said she was so proud of her little girl.She said: Im so proud of Kaitlyn. At the time I wasnt really aware of what had happened.I woke up with the paramedics standing over me. I was so happy when I found out what she had done.”Charlene suffers from a medical condition that causes her to have non-epileptic seizures and had taught her children how to call an ambulance in an emergency.She added: We taught all our children how to make a  call, and what to say to the call handler. We got Kaitlyn a pretend Disney phone and practised with it.It can be scary when youre not well. But Kaitlyn makes me feel safe. Shes a star.Her husband, Simon, added: Kaitlyn is a grown-up little girl who knows exactly what to do in an emergency. She was brilliant.Jess Hodkinson, the call handler who took Kaitlyns call on October , said this proved how important it is for parents to teach their children how to call .She said: Every call is dferent, and we are taught how to deal with child callers as part of our training.But it is unusual to receive a call from someone so young.Kaitlyn was very brave and informative.She obviously knew how to call , she told me exactly what was happening, and where they lived.She knew exactly what to do in an emergency.Kaitlyn was awarded a special certicate on Friday on behalf of South Western Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust SWASFT chief executive Ken Wenman.A spokesman for the South Western Ambulance Service told the Daily Mirror: During the call Kaitlyn showed extraordinary bravery, presence of mind, and wisdom beyond her years.Thankfully, her mum made a recovery, and didnt need paramedics to treat her.

story: In an incendiary intervention, the EU Council chief said there was no chance that EU leaders would renegotiate the PM’s agreement.And speaking at the G in Argentina, he saidthe Commons rejects it, the UK would be left with No Deal, or No Brexit.He added: “I want to reassure you that the EU is prepared for every scenario.”The move incensed Brexiteers who accused the Eurocrat of “arrogant meddling”. Arch Eurosceptic Iain Duncan Smith said: “Advice from someone none of the British public voted for should be put in the bin.”But just hours later Labour Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell delighted pro-EU campaigners by insisting that ‘Remain’ would have to be on the ballot paper in a second Referendum.He told Talk Radio there should be an option to “throw the whole thing out and stop Brexit altogether”.The double whammy piled pressure on Theresa May – who is facing a crushing defeat in the Commons on December  with more than  Tory MPs poised to vote against her proposed deal with Brussels.The PM’s official spokesman yesterday insisted Mr Tusk’s remarks echoed previous statements where he had expressed his sorrow that Britain was leaving. He added: “The Prime Minister is very clear, we are leaving the European Union on March .”But Mr Tusk’s comments echo a veiled threat from Mrs May in recent days to rebel Tories – where she has warned a vote against her deal could prevent Brexit altogether.Speaking to a mutinous House of Commons on Monday she said: “No one knows what will happenthis deal doesn’t pass.”Yesterday in Argentina, the PM took the startling step of warning her furious Brexiteer Tories they were threatening their own constituents’ jobsthey vote against her.This was backed by a Tory Party social media campaign where members of the public urge MPs to support her deal.Trade Secretary Liam Fox yesterday warned a “schism” could open up between Parliament and the rest of the country.And he said Donald Tusk’s comments brought the choices facing MPs “into stark relief”. He said: “For me, failing to honour the referendum would not only be undemocratic, but I think it would be quite dangerous in terms of the way that the public view the political establishment in the United Kingdom.“I thinkthe public vote for Brexit, and Parliament were to try and steal that from the British public, then I think that would create a real schism between Parliament and the electorate.”

title: paloma faith new mum is difficult
story: “Motherhood was much more dficult than I anticipated because I hadn’t heard the truth and I think not enough people speak about it,” Paloma said. “Obviously everyone’s experience is dferent and I have met mums who sailed through it but I didn’t. I was really shell-shocked.”It seems like such a simple admission. But the reality is that with most celebrities, from the Kardashians to the Beckhams, projecting an unfeasibly perfect image of parenthood as part of their brand, many expectant mums think a new baby is going to be a walk in the park.The reality for most of us really couldn’t be further from the truth.Paloma also talked about the dficulty of balancing being a new mother with having a career.“I found it very dficult, the pull between wanting to be the greatest mother ever but also trying to sustain an inherently selfish career,” she said.The transition from being a woman with a career and all the time in the world to a mother wanting to continue working is no easy feat.There’s a period of adjustment and, often, the road is rocky. So here’s the reality, for what it’s worth.In my experience, EVERY woman who is a parent finds motherhood hard at some point or ­another, but especially at the beginning. And the women who seem to be sailing through it are often putting on a brave face, partly because they feel under pressure to do so.Often, people’s public portrayal of their le, including motherhood, is heavily edited, airbrushed and ­censored.The pressure on women for everything, including motherhood, to be “perfect” is clear.And,that isn’t your experience, with everyone  seemingly acing it, the pressure is on to pretend that it is.The vicious cycle is born. So it’s brave of Paloma to talk about her experience out loud.Given that every mum in the history of the universe has felt this way about motherhood at one time or another, we should be more honest about admitting it to be true.Modern pressures are making it so dficult I have to say I’m so glad I’m not raising a child today.The internet had still not been invented. The Twitter and Instagram inventors had probably not even been born.When I was growing up the only “influencers” in my le were my mum and dad.We ate as a family every night and there were three channels on the TV that all stopped airing by midnight. You had to make your own entertainment.Nowadays you can’t move for influencers on YouTube, Instagram and Twitter telling your kids how they should look or feel — and ­promoting lestyles that are simply unattainable.No wonder there has been such a dramatic rise in young people self-harming and taking anti- depressants. Too many influencers, who are hashtag “blessed”, don’t talk about the dficult stuff.Paloma, by the way, is raising her child as “gender neutral” — a ­decision that seems to be another indication of the pressures that ­people are under to do the right thing by their children.Too much choice and too much pressure to do the right thing and be the perfect parent can lead to paranoia.The best advice I could give a parent now that my own two are  and  is to find your own path.Don’t look too hard at what everyone  is doing.Don’t compare yourself to any other mothers, especially not celebrities with a team of personal trainers and chefs, and who snap back into shape two weeks after giving birth.Instead of aiming for perfect, just try to do your best.Listen, understand and give your child the one thing that really does matter: Self-esteem.Talk to other women, and be honest, evenyou are finding it hard. Because it IS bloody hard.So good for Paloma for being honest and fighting the tide of propaganda about motherhood.Because being honest makes it easier for other women who might be struggling.ISN’T it incredible to think that a hundred years ago, on November , , women were allowed to stand for parliament in the UK for the very first time Fast forward to the  General Election when  female MPs were elected.Yes, that’s in relation to  male MPs, so we still have a way to go – but look how far we have come.I know I am biased, but women are such a brilliant parliamentary asset.Look at all the things they bring to the table and to the conversation.Women are great listeners, good mediators, brilliant diplomats and inspiring promoters of family and equal rights. Oh, and we are resilient.Just look at Theresa May who, at a time when most men would be hiding under the duvet and emitting a high-pitched wailing noise, is rising to the unbelievable challenges being thrown at her by the Brexit process – and enjoying beans on toast with her husband Philip in the evening.Compare her to a politician such as Jacob Rees-Mogg who is doing everything he possibly can to promote himself and his political ambitions – rather than focusing on what the country needs.The PM is the living embodiment of resilience – a tough old bird indeed.ANYONE in a long-term marriage should take note of Dolly Parton’s insights on what makes her -year union work.“When people ask me what’s the key to my long marriage and lasting love, I always say, ‘Stay gone’,” the singer, reveals. “I travel a lot, but we really enjoy each other when we’re together and the little things we do.”Her husband Carl doesn’t like to appear in public or walk the red carpet – so she leaves him at home.Instead of glamorous date nights, they take trips in a “little camper”, go on picnics and eat at local restaurants, including a drive-thru McDonald’s.But eventhey are having a quiet night in, she says she always makes sure she is “fixed up for him because I don’t believe in going home and being a slouch”.You’ve got to love Dolly.NOT many people can ooze class, charm and elegance with their leg raised higher than their head – at the age of .Butthere’s one woman who can, it’s the glorious Darcey Bussell, who must be one of the nicest, and classiest, women in showbiz today.Goldman was one of the first corporate firms to introduce “lactation rooms” for women to express milk and it also runs free prenatal fitness classes at its office gym.It also has on-site day care where employees’ children are cared for  days per year for free.All of which is great – and let’s hope more companies follow suit for new parents.Mind you, it’s not like the need for childcare ever really stops – I still need an emergency nanny occasionally when my -year-old daughter loses her keys or my -year-old son locks himself out.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bankrupt tory council given permission
story: NewsBankrupt Tory council given permission to sell off HQ to bail itself outConservative-run Northamptonshire Council is trying to avoid falling into insolvency for the third time in a yearShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsThe council is looking to sell its headquarters to plug its funding gap "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Bankrupt Tory council has been given permission to bail itself out using up to pound million raised by selling off its headquarters. Conservative-run Northamptonshire became the first council in  years to ban all new spending when it ran out of cash in February. It still needs to plug a pound million budget gap before the end of March to avoid falling into insolvency for the third time. And now ministers have launched a consultation on breaking the crisis-hit authority up. Usually councils are banned from using income from the sale of buildings to pay for day-to-day expenses. But in move thought to be unprecedented, the Government has granted permission to Northamptonshire Council to do so in a bid to avoid going insolvent for the third time in less than a year. But opposition councillors said it was a political move to avoid ministers having to step in directly to bail out the council.   Labour group leader Mick Scrimshaw told the : “It is clearly politics. The Conservative government did not want the political embarrassment and for that reason they have been allowed to use these capital receipts.” One plan to balance the books, first mooted in February, is selling the councils new poundmillion headquarters in Angel Square, Northampton, and then leasing the building back. Government-appointed commissioners asked for permission for what is known as a capitalisation request in its first report to Communities Secretary in September. The Government said it would allow the council to tap its capital receipts, calling it a signicant step. Under the usual rules, there must be a clear separation between capital income - like sales on council-owned land and buildings - and revenue, including wages, salaries and running costs. But commissioners said finding an alternative to plug the revenue hole was unavoidable. The commissioners were sent in on May  to bring the councils finances back under control. In July, an initial audit revealed the councils finances were considerably worse than first thought and the local authority was on track to have a deficit of between pound million and pound million by the end of the financial year. Commissioners have already overseen the appointment of a new chief executive and finance director.   In a statement Communities Secretary James Brokenshire said: Clearly, the situation in Northamptonshire is very serious. I am grateful to the commissioners for uncovering the councils true financial position and the robust steps they have taken to improve its financial management and governance. There is still much to do, but I fully support their resolve to ensure the people of Northamptonshire receive the efficient, effective and sustainable services they deserve. Separately, the Government launched a consultation on proposals to break up the local authority, creating two new unitary authorities covering the north and west of Northamptonshire. That plan would create one authority area encompassing , people, including the towns of Kettering and Corby, and a second area including Northampton and managing services for , people. The proposals could save pound million by . But transition costs were estimated to reach up to pound million,the plans got the Government go-ahead. In a statement to the House of Commons on Thursday, Mr Brokenshire said he would make a final decision on whether to implement the proposals after the consultation ends in late January. He added that the Government would also be tabling measures to postpone district and parish council elections, due to be held in May, until .

title: g20 summit photos say everything
story: G summit photos say everything you need to know about world politics in Donald Trump, Vladimir Putin, Theresa May and the Saudi Crown Prince are among leaders meeting - and clashing - in Buenos Aires. Its a cliché, but the pictures really do say a thousand wordsShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  NOV NewsWorld leaders from the  major economies pose for a family photo at this years summit Our  most powerful leaders have met at the G summit - and it is a fractured time for the world.Russias Vladimir Putin faces condemnation over the Salisbury Novichok attack and his regimes behaviour in Ukraine.Saudi Arabias Crown Prince is a pariah - well, except in Russias eyess - over the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi.And US President Donald Trump is at once the centre of attention after his many disputes over trade, not to mention his ex-lawyer lying about his links with Russia.Battling her own dficulties at the summit in Buenos Aires, Argentina, is Theresa May.The UK Prime Minister is facing almost certain defeat for her Brexit deal on December  in Parliament, and she wasnt helped by some of her fellow world leaders.President Trump said it could make it harder to get a UK-US trade deal - something Mrs May denied. And EU chief Donald Tusk hinted Brexit could be cancelledit all goes to pot.It all could be, and has been, described with thousands of words. But sometimes, even though its a cliché, the photos say more than we ever could. Theyre the two pariahs of the world. So it seems only natural that Russias President Vladimir Putin and Saudi Arabias Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman would smile and high-five at the summit. Saudi Arabia is accused of complicity in a journalists murder while Russia is accused of a state-sponsored nerve agent murder on British soil.  of Theresa May was caught in a candid moment walking away from the EU - quite literally. Behind her, French President Emmanuel Macron and European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker were spotted having a quiet word. The EU and UK have an agreement on Brexit, but President Macron has threatened to scupper it by demanding the right to fish in UK waters.  of Donald Trump cancelled a meeting with Russias Vladimir Putin at the last moment as his ex-lawyer, Michael Cohen, admitted lying to Congress about a Trump real estate project linked to the country. The President claimed he pulled the plug on the meeting in Argentina over Russians treatment of the Ukraine. Trump cited tensions over Russian forces opening fire on Ukrainian navy boats and then seizing them and their crew on Sunday near Crimea, which Russia annexed from Ukraine in .  of President Trump was the centre of attention as he signed a new trade pact with Canadas Justin Trudeau and Mexicos outgoing leader, Enrique Pena Nieto - celebrating his last day in office. Despite all their history - and a deal only being reached at the last minute - the trio managed to agree a replacement for the North American Free Trade Agreement. Its been long and hard. Weve taken a lot of barbs and a little abuse and we got there, Trump said after the signing.  of Theresa May cut a lonely figure as she arrived at midnight in Argentina on her RAF jet. On a -hour flight she insisted she could still get her Brexit deal through Parliament despite  Tory MPs indicated they are prepared to vote against it. And she grumpily batted aside questions about what will happenit doesnt get through.  of Its back! The Baby Trump balloon that made a name for itself in London, where the President visited in July, is seen ahead of the G leaders summit, in front of the Congress building in Buenos Aires.  of Donald Trump is a dficult character - and pulled some dficult faces during the leaders session on the first of two days of the summit.  of Theresa May proudly describes herself as a bloody dficult woman, so she pulled some pretty tricky faces in the meeting too.  of There was high security around the summit as protesters gathered against it - a familiar sight at the annual bash. In  the  members represented % of the entire worlds economy, two-thirds of its population and % of its trade.  of Donald Trump met Theresa May for the first time since he slated her Brexit deal. The President said it sounded like a great deal for the EU that would stop the UK being able to trade freely with the US.  of The UK Prime Minister hit back today, saying: Im very happy to tell President Trump and others that we will have an independent trade policy, because we will have an independent trade policy, we will be able to do trade deals.  of But no matter what happens, the US Presidents force of personality suggests he - and his Twitter account - would end up making most of the headlines from the big weekend.  of More OnPoliticsG- SummitCommentsShow more comments

title: hire british youngsters theresa tells
story: NewsHire British youngsters Theresa May tells firms as EU migration plummetsThe fall in the pound has made the UK less attractive for would-be workersShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsThe Prime Minister had a message for business as she touched down in Argentina "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBosses should stop moaning about a lack of low-skilled foreign workers and start employing British youngsters instead, Theresa May insisted. Net migration from the EU has plummeted since the  Brexit vote. The fall in the value of the pound has made it less attractive for would-be workers to up sticks and come to the UK for jobs. Firms have warned of a “Brexodus” as companies find it harder to recruit from poorer nations on the continent. Annual net EU migration is running at , – the lowest since , figures showed this week, as the number of European nationals quitting the UK surged by % year-on-year to ,. Universities minister Sam Gyimah becomes seventh minister latest to quit over Brexit dealIn a sign of simmering tensions between No  and industry, the Prime Minister hit out at executives who claim a post-withdrawal clampdown on overseas workers will stle their business. Tackled about the complaints from managers and directors that it will be too dficult to fill low-skilled positions, she fumed: “We have seen a huge, signicant creation of new jobs in our country and we have also seen from work the Government is doing, our encouragement of people into the workplace. “What I hope to see – and what Im sure we will be seeing - is opportunities for young people in the UK, opportunities for training and skilling young people in the UK. “But we recognise that there are businesses who want to bring people in from the rest of the world, particularly in highly-skilled areas, and our immigration system will reflect that.” Pointing to the findings of the Migration Advisory Committee, she suggested highly-skilled foreigners would stand a better chance of finding a job in the UK than less-skilled counterparts after Brexit.  “They have said they think a skills-based immigration system is the way to go, and thats what we will be doing,” said the PM, as she flew to Argentina for the G summit. “We are talking to business about their needs.” No  has refused to say when it will publish its long-term immigration policy.But ministers have repeatedly pointed out Brexit will finally allow the Government to treat EU migrants the same as those from outside the bloc.Quitting the EU would allow the UK to stop unlimited migration from the continent, she added.“Crucially we are bringing free movement to an end,” said Mrs May. “It enables us to have one system for people coming from across the world, and that is skills-based and recognises the needs of the economy.”

title: mohammed bin salman tells macron
story: NewsMohammed bin Salman tells Macron dont worry in tense talk about Khashoggi murderEmmanuel Macron confronted Saudi Arabia Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman regarding the murder of Saudi dissident journalist Jamal KhashoggiShareCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video mbs-tells-macron-dont-worry-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEmmanuel Macron confronted Saudi Arabian Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman over the murder of Jamal Khashoggi at the G summit. The French President told the de-facto Saudi ruler that international experts need to be involved in the investigation into his death. Mr Macrons demand came shortly before Theresa May held face-to-face talks with the crown prince in which she promised to send a robust message about the murder, as well as the war in Yemen. Bin Salman has appeared isolated among fellow world leaders at the G summit in Argentina, with the exception of a vigorous public handshake from Russias Vladimir Putin - himself treated as a pariah by some of those present. The crown prince was filmed in an apparently tense conversation with Mr Macron, telling the French president not to worry. Mr Macron responded: I am worried...You never listen to me.   The widely-shared video showed bin Salman replying: I will listen, of course. It concluded with Mr Macron saying: I am a man of my word. Later, an Elysee Palace official said the president had conveyed a very firm message on the need for international involvement in the Khashoggi investigation, currently the subject of two separate probes by Saudi Arabia and Turkey. Mrs May said she would use her meeting to press Britains call for a credible and transparent investigation into Mr Khashoggis death in the Saudi consulate in Istanbul in October and urge Mohammed to ensure his country offers full co-operation to the Turkish investigation.   Mrs May was also pressing the Crown Prince to ensure his countrys engagement in talks in Stockholm next week to find a political solution to the bloodshed in Yemen, where a Saudi-led coalition is fighting Houthi rebels. Amnesty International UKs director Kate Allen said Mrs May should politely but firmly insist that only a UN investigation into the grisly murder of Jamal Khashoggi is going to be sufficient. Speaking to Sky News ahead of the meeting, Mrs May said: It is the relationship we have with Saudi Arabia that enables me to sit down with him and be robust on our views on two issues. On the Khashoggi case, she said Riyadh must ensure that their investigation is a full investigation, that it is credible, that it is transparent and that people can have confidence in the outcome of it and that those responsible are held to account.   And she said she was very concerned about the humanitarian situation in Yemen resulting from the long-running conflict. Now is the time, there is an opportunity to find a solution, said the PM. I will be encouraging all parties, including the Saudi Arabians, to ensure that they sit down at the upcoming UN-led talks in Stockholm in the coming days and weeks and find a way through this, find a political solution for a stable future for Yemen. Mrs May also held talks with the summits host, President Mauricio Macri, at which the long-standing dispute over the sovereignty of the Falklands took a back seat as discussions focused on trade.   Mrs May presented keen Queen fan Macri with a book about the rock band, while the Argentine president gave her a special cup for drinking national beverage Yerba Mate herbal tea. Mrs May is the first Conservative Prime Minister to visit Argentina since the  war, and only the second serving PM to do so, after Tony Blair briefly crossed the border from Brazil in . Mr Macri has toned down official rhetoric over the islands Argentina knows as Las Malvinas since taking over from Cristina Kirchner in . This weeks announcement of a new air link between the Falklands and the South American mainland via Argentina has been greeted in London as an indication that relations are headed in a positive direction. Speaking during her flight to Buenos Aires, Mrs May said the establishment of the flight showed a dferent relationship developing. I am talking to President Macri about issues about trade and opportunities for trade, but our position on the sovereignty of the Falklands hasnt changed and will not change, she added.

title: strictly brexit tv debates need
story: NewsopinionThe Strictly Brexit TV debates need to be done properly - with Theresa, Jeremy, and Craig Revel HorwoodAny chance of a phone vote, too ShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  NOV Newsopinion"Get Im a Celebrity updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe idea of a second season of Brexit debates may well be the least welcome franchise reboot in television history.But hang on - theyre going to be linked to Im A Celebrity and Strictly Come Dancing, you say  Book Craig Revel Horwood and buy some fresh kangaroo balls! LETS DO THIS.In the opening credits, a glitterball with the word SOVEREIGNTY flies in across the Australian rainforest. The camera pans to a grim-faced Tess Daly, stood in Elstree Studios in army fatigues and camouflage paint. Good evening and welcome to Strictly Brexit... Get Me Out Of Here! Next to her, Declan Donnelly - in a gorgeous pink floaty ballgown perfect for the Viennese waltz - shouts: Its politics week, and our final contestants are going head-to-head in the shout-off. Please welcome, Theresa May and Jeremy Corbyn!The studio audience clap despondently in the trees as Theresa abseils to the ground dressed as a giant sequinned eagle . Jeremy joins her in a small wheeled kayak filled with cockroaches all muttering about Palestine.The two take up position at podiums in the centre of the dancefloor, as forest rangers screw large, transparent plastic boxes to their heads.  Dec adopts his concerned voice as he says: Theresa and Jeremy, you have  minutes to convince the public your version of Brexit will work. But you will not be alone out there.Tess continues: Theresa, you will have , miniature backbenchers added to your box. For legal reasons, I must warn you they can bite, but will probably not manage a decent coup detat.Dec turns to her opponent. Jeremy, your box contains enough oxygen for you to survive. But every time you do that shouty geography teacher thing, ask Diane Abbott for help or fail to pick a side, some of your oxygen will be removed. He continues: Keir Starmer will also stand behind you, whispering things you dont understand. Tess then indicates a camp fire around which are gathered Bruno Tonioli, Shirley Ballas, Darcey Bussell and Craig Revel Horwood. Please welcome our judges, who will deliver their verdict on your technical performance. You will be subject to a phone vote and at the end of the show one of you WILL be leaving the contest. Spotlights fall upon the pair, and Theresa speaks first. Im standing up for Britain, she begins, then squeaks as a Jacob bites her on the nose and tells her shes hysterical. This is a deal that will give us control of our borders, she continues, while an Arlene crawls into her ear demanding Northern Ireland has special treatment but is also treated just the same. This is the best we could hope for, she adds as a Boris slithers down her blouse looking for his point.Jeremy then takes his turn. We respect the referendum, but were going to stop the government acting on it, he says, with a cough. Theresa has botched the deal, and we could do a better onewe just go back to the start again, he gasps. A second referendum is an option but we prefer a... general election... we had a peoples vote already...he continues breathlessly, going blue in the face.Nobody is ruling out remain, Keir whispers. Jeremys eyes bulge. Keir goes on: We need single market access or the economy will collapse. Jeremy begins clawing at his box. John McDonnell isnt your friend any more, hisses Keir, as Jeremy tries to smash the box against the podium.Tess and Dec practice their sad faces. And now, lets ask our judges for advice, says Tess. Darcey  Are you an enemy of the people   The former ballerina lts her head from her hands. Theresa, your framing was excellent but the footwork makes no sense. You need to really point those toes, yes, arch your nose a little more, yes She collapses back into ennui as Bruno leaps to his feet, grinds his pelvis and shouts: THERESA THE PLEASER! My God, woman, the way you travelled the floor with those backbenchers trying to destroy you reminded me of Anton du Beke and Ann Widdecombe. You are the one to beat, but I must admit my darling the footwork was a little illogical, you havent really sold it to me. The camera pans to Craig, whose face resembles the morning after a whisky bottle and a bad break-up. The whole thing has been a dis-AAAAAAAA-ster, darlings. Neither of you made me happy, you both fudged your fleckles, and Im afraid the only paddle youll see is when the nation tells you both to get in the sea, darling.Dec turns to Shirley. Youre head judge and have the casting vote. What do you think  Shirley titters: Oh I agree with all my fellow judges! Arent they great! Were best friends!  Tess turns to Theresa, by this point writhing on the floor as a tiny Andrew Bridgen kicks her in the teeth, and Jeremy, who has gone purple while being throttled by Keir Starmers Blairite tie.We go now to the results of the phone vote. Jeremy, you got... NO votes of approval. Theresa, you got... NO votes of approval. So we go to the votes of disapproval, she says.She takes a deep breath. Jeremy, you got disapproval votes from the majority of your shadow cabinet, your parliamentary party, and your party membership as a whole. Theresa, you got parliamentary disapproval votes only from Boris, Jacob and their friends, but also Im afraid the vast majority of your party members, Brexiters, Remainers, and readers of the .Overall, neither of you has won. So we go to sudden death.A crash of drums, and a spotlight falls upon stage left. Dec says: You will now present your business plans to Claude Littner. Claude enters, flanked by feather-covered dancers. This is a bloody disgrace!, he barks. Theresa, none of your figures add up. Ive read through your deal and its exceptional. Exceptionally BAD, that is. If this had been suggested on day  it would have been laughed out. And Jeremy. Youre talking nonsense, arent you  Quite clearly the statements youre making are ludicrous. Youre not a big fish. Youre not even a fish! Frankly, youre both parasites. This contest is terminated.Claude exits. Tess and Dec look at each other and the cameras, uncertain of what to do. In their earpieces, a producer wonders about the wisdom of getting Mr Blobby on with a bucket of crocodile eyes. Bollocks to this, says a member of the audience, standing up. Youre all hopeless. No-one voted for the Tories to disentegrate, no-ones pointed out this is a transition agreement, not the actual deal. If youre all this hopeless just limbering up, what hope do we have of winning the thing  Ive heard enough. Youre all bloody fired.  We wont get any that, of course. Those who organise political debates rarely include a gunge machine, and politicians who behave like infants whove lost a rattle ironically think such stunts would be childish.Instead, the broadcasters will put the debate on just before the Im A Celeb final or after the Strictly semi-final. The question is not who gets voted out, but whether its a BBC audience, a more-plebby ITV one, and whether anyone will watch for more than  minutes.Which is a shame, because as a country we have more faith in X Factor phone votes than we do the ones cast in the ballot box.

title: theresa confronts mohammad bin salman
story: NewsTheresa May pictured next to underfire Mohammad bin Salman in G summit meetingPrime Minister Theresa May spoke with the de-facto Saudi leader at the G summit in Buenos AiresShareCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsTheresa May with Mohammed bin Salman Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia as they hold a bilateral meeting at the G summit in Buenos Aires, Argentina "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May posed for a picture next to underfire Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman as she confronted him about the killing of Jamal Khashoggi. The Prime Minister spoke with the de-facto Saudi leader at the G summit in Buenos Aires. Bin Salman has been linked to the murder of the Saudi journalist however has always strongly denied giving the order the kill or knowing of the plot. Following Mrs Mays meeting with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, a Downing Street spokesman said: The Prime Minister stressed the importance of ensuring that those responsible for the appalling murder of Jamal Khashoggi are held to account, and that Saudi Arabia takes action to build confidence that such a deplorable incident could not happen again.  Noting the steps taken by the Saudi investigation since the Foreign Secretary had met with the Crown Prince and King Salman on  November, she encouraged the Crown Prince to ensure that Saudi Arabia co-operated fully with the Turkish authorities and worked to bring both investigations to an acceptable close. To ensure full accountability, there needed to be full transparency about exactly what had happened and who was responsible, in line with the commitments made by King Salman when she spoke to him on October .  On Yemen, the Prime Minister set out the urgent need to bring an end to the conflict and bring relief to millions threatened by famine. She urged concrete Saudi support for UN Special Envoy Martin Grfiths and for progress at the upcoming Stockholm talks. The Prime Minister stressed that the humanitarian situation remained dire and reaffirmed UK commitment to making progress on improving the situation, including through a UN Security Council Resolution. The Prime Minister reiterated UK support for Saudi Arabias security, including the very real threats posed by Iranian interference in Yemen. story: NewsEmirates Boeing  takes off immediately after hard landing during Storm DianaAviation enthusiast Jonathan Winton took the nerve-wracking clip at Newcastle AirportShareCommentsByDave Burke:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video terrying-aborted-landing-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailShocking footage shows a plane having to take off immediately after a hard landing forced it to abort its first attempt.The clip was taken by plane enthusiast Jonathan Winton at Newcastle Airport on Thursday. An Emirates Boeing , arriving from Dubai, was caught in heavy crosswinds during Storm Diana. Explaining what happened, Mr Winton posted on YouTube: The wind had been gusting at around  [mph] to kts [mph] this Thursday morning. Having established on the approach for runway  and been cleared to land by the controller, it looked like a normal approach in the challenging crosswinds from the south.  As the  disappeared behind the hedge before touching down, it slammed down onto runway , the spoilers deployed, and the next thing full power was applied for a go around. Ive never seen anything like it here at Newcastle Airport. The aircraft then came in for a second approach and landed safely. Upon landing the aircraft was inspected and initially there was thought to be damage to the rear landing gear. Upon further inspection though it was deemed safe to fly and the aircraft departed Newcastle for Dubai  minutes later than planned. Dai Whittingham, chief executive of the UK Flight Safety Committee, told Mail Online : High winds in themselves are not dangerous but they can certainly be inconvenient, especiallythe wind direction is across the runway.All pilots train to land in high crosswind conditions and will have practiced to the aircraft limits in the simulator. Gardener Mr Winton, , of Alnwick, Northumberland, said: The winds didnt feel particularly strong at first but as we got a bit higher up they suddenly hit.  Im a huge aviation fan so for me it was incredible to watch, but for those with a fear of flying it must have been pretty hair-raising. A spokesperson for Newcastle International Airport confirmed that there were no cancellations or delays as a result of Storm Diana.

story: NewsFatcat rail bosses enjoy bumper % payrise while commuters face % rail fare hikeThe cost of many rail season tickets will increase by more than £ from JanuaryShareCommentsByNick Sommerlad:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsGo Ahead’s chief executive David Brown got paid £.m last year, up %"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBritain’s fatcat rail bosses enjoyed a bumper % average payrise last year – as commuters were hit by news that their rail fares are being hiked by % next year. But Rail, Maritime and Transport union general secretary Mick Cash said the latest fare rise is “another kick in the teeth for passengers on Britain’s rip-off privatised railways”. The RMT’s Mick Cash added: “We are constantly being told there is not enough money to employ station staff and guards but when it comes to boardroom pay on Britain’s rip-off railways the sky’s the limit. “This news will just add to passenger anger after the latest fare hike.” From January  next year, the price of a season ticket from Brighton to London will go up by pound to pound,, while one from Gloucester to Birmingham goes up pound to to pound, and one from Manchester to Liverpool goes up pound to pound,. He added: “Taxpayers already subsidise the network by more than pound billion a year - meaning that % of our transport budget is spent on the % of journeys that the railway accounts for.” Shadow transport secretary Andy McDonald claimed the increase shows “a Government and rail industry out of touch with passenger concerns”.A spokesman for the Rail Delivery Group, said: “Director’s pay is set according to market rates to attract the people needed to run big,complex safety-critical companies that move millions of passengers every day.”

title: five nations running build royal
story: NewsFive nations in running to build Royal Navy ships - but only one bid is BritishThe MoD said companies from Italy, Spain, Japan and South Korea were in the running for the bumper contract – with a UK consortium also shortlistedShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  NOV NewsHMS-Sutherland pictured in  - as firms from five nations battle it out for contracts "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFive nations are in the running to build Royal Navy supply ships, the Ministry of Defence has revealed. The competition to design and construct the Fleet Solid Support vessels for the Royal Fleet Auxiliary unleashed a major political row after the Tories claimed they were not warships – even though they will be armed and steam into battle zones. That meant the poundbillion deal to build two, possibly three vessels, could be offered to foreign shipyards – potentially denying British workers and firms a massive windfall. The MoD said companies from Italy, Spain, Japan and South Korea were in the running for the bumper contract – with a UK consortium also shortlisted.   The British team is made up of leading manufacturing and engineering companies Babcock, BAE Systems, Cammell Laird and Rolls-Royce. They join Italian firm Fincantieri, Spanish company Navantia, Japan Marine United Corporation, and Daewoo Shipbuilding and Marine Engineering of South Korea as the firms invited to submit a tender for the competition. Defence Minister Stuart Andrew said: “The widespread interest in this competition shows that our Royal Navy and Royal Fleet Auxiliary remain among the most prestigious in the world.   “These support ships will be vital for supporting our formidable Queen Elizabeth-class carriers and will ensure our warships can deploy in a range of challenging environments and across huge distances, wherever they are in the world.” The winning bidder will be announced in . Unions and Labour have called for the ships to be built in Britain to boost UK industry and give a steady workflow to skilled British employees. The vessels will restock Navy destroyers, frigates and aircraft carriers at seas with food, ammunition and other supplies.   They are due to enter service in . Shipbuilding and Engineering Union general secretary Ian Waddell said: “The Government are insisting that these ships are not warships so that they can open the contracts up to international competition in order to save money.   “The reality is that since the end of the aircraft carrier project  shipbuilding jobs have been lost in the UK, one yard has been closed and another is under threat. “By classying these ships, which carry weapons and support the carrier strike capability, as warships, which they do in other EU countries, we can design, manufacture and maintain these ships in the UK and guarantee jobs for a generation.

story: NewsIncredible recording of girl, , who helped save mum by calling Kaitlyn Wright, from Askerswell, near Dorchester, Dorset, has made mother-of-three Charlene "the proudest mum in the world"ShareCommentsByAmber Hicks:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video incredible-recording-girl--who-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA four-year-old girl who rang  when her mum started having seizures at home has been praised for her quick-thinking actions.Kaitlyn Wright told the emergency services operator mum Charlene was having a fit and that she needed to look after her. When the call handler asked the youngstershe was there alone, the youngster replied: Its just me. And a dog and a kitten. Kaitlyn tried to direct the operator to the family home by telling them to go down the big hill and up the other side. The operator was able to trace the call and ambulance paramedics rushed to the address in Askerswell, near Dorchester, Dorset.  Luckily Charlene recovered by the time the ambulance turned up  minutes later and she was checked over. The -year-old said today: I just cant explain how very proud I am of Kaitlyn. I am the proudest mum in the world right now, shes just wonderful. It was quite scary for Kaitlyn to see me have a fit but she was so calm and chilled about it. Charlene suffers from fibromyalgia syndromewhich leaves her in constant pain and prone to regular seizures.  Because of her condition she had spoken to all three of her children and practiced how to call for an ambulance so they knew what to do in an emergency. Charlene said she is rarely home alone with just Kaitlyn but on this occasion her older daughter Ky, , and Kayden, , were out. Charlene said: Kaitlyns dad had seen her in the morning and then brought her back home. He askedI wanted some shopping and I said yes. Kaitlyn wanted to stay at home with me, we wouldnt normally be at home just the two of us, I try to avoid it in case something does happen.  I was lying in bed and felt quite comfortable at the time but Id had a bad week and had been in a lot of pain. The pain gets so much that my body basically reboots like a computer because it cant handle the level of pain. The next thing I knew was the paramedic looking at me. I dont really remember much. Ive been having the seizures for about five or six months and taught all the kids what to do, weve practiced on the phone, pretending to call  so theyd know what to do.  During the phone call Kaitlyn tried to direct them to the house,telling them to go down the big hill from the A and up the other side. I dont think she realises how great she was but I told her well done and what a great job she had done. Today Kaitlyn and her mum are due to visit the South Western Ambulance Service control centre near Bristol to the call handler the youngster spoke.  Kaitlyn will also been given a special certicate for her actions. A spokesman for the South Western Ambulance Service said: During the call Kaitlyn showed extraordinary bravery, presence of mind, and wisdom beyond her years. Thankfully, her mum made a recovery, and didnt need paramedics to treat her.

title: margaret thatcher turned back lockerbie
story: NewsMargaret Thatcher turned her back on Lockerbie victims to cut compensation billTop Tories meeting in No were wrongly told none of the dead passengers were BritishShareCommentsByNick Sommerlad:,  NOV NewsMargaret Thatcher’s cold-hearted Cabinet discussed minimising the cost of compensating Lockerbie disaster - hours after it happened "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMargaret Thatcher’s cold-hearted Cabinet discussed minimising the cost of compensating Lockerbie disaster victims just hours after the terror attack. Top Tories meeting in No were wrongly told none of the dead passengers were British and that the houses of victims on the ground would be insured, a confidential memo reveals. It would emerge  of the  passengers on the doomed flight were British, as was one of the  crew. Another  perished in their homes when wreckage from Pan Am Flight  hit the Scottish village of Lockerbie  years ago this month. Jim Swire, , whose daughter Flora died in the bombing, described the document as “callous and calculating”. It comes as another confidential memo revealed officials thought families of Lockerbie terror attack victims needed “careful watching”. Relatives, including Dr Swire – a vocal critic of the Government’s response to the attack – claim they have been repeatedly bugged by security services. The Mirror has unearthed a confidential minute of the Cabinet meeting at .am on December , , the morning after the tragedy.  Ministers were told “there would be a general expectation that a disaster fund would be established” that “the Government would contribute to it” and that “it would be a mistake to preicate over this”. But a memo found in the National Archives continues: “On the other hand, neither the aircraft nor its passengers were British and it was not yet clear that many people on the ground would require assistance. “The private houses affected would presumably be covered by insurance.” There was no mention in the document that the Government should feel morally obliged to help or that it should take the lead and set up a fund.  Instead, Mrs Thatcher told colleagues the Government would make “an appropriate contribution”a fund was opened. An emergency fund was announced by the local council that same day and then Transport Secretary Paul Channon told the Commons “the Government will contribute in the normal way”. The minutes also reveal Mrs Thatcher ordered Mr Channon to spin the response to the atrocity. She said he “should give as much detail as he could about major shyoperations that were being mounted in response to this tragedy” and “it was important that it should be as positive as possible”.   The Government was soon engulfed in criticism that it failed to pass on a warning from American authorities on December  that a Pan Am flight from Frankfurt to the US could be a terror target within two weeks. Mr Channon said this information was not passed on to British airlines or airports as it had little credibility. Dr Swire, a GP who became the face of a campaign for a public inquiry into the atrocity, said of the memo: “If I had known about it at the time my first response would have been shyastonishment and fury.   “It seems callous to me and calculating that hours after the bombing the Government is counting the cost to itself, and looking at ways of minimising that cost. I would have thought that the Cabinet would have been urging their most powerful investigators to discover whether they played any part in allowing this atrocity to happen. You couldn’t make it up, could you  It is stunning.” Medical student Flora Swire, , was sitting in seat D on Pam Am Flight . Dr Swire added: “I was completely done on that day. It took me a long time to recover my voice.”   He and another Lockerbie relative claimed they were bugged as confidential documents revealed they needed “careful watching”. The grieving dad said: “They have been listening in to our communications and concealing something they didn’t want us to know.” Mrs Thatcher had been warned families were getting increasingly organised and it was suggested they should be put under observation. A letter from the Foreign Office on August , , to Lord Fraser of Carmyllie, shyScotland’s most senior law officer, said: “Another aspect which will need careful watching is the activities of relatives of Pan Am  victims.   “The US relatives have for some time been well organised and vocal. More recently the UK relatives have formed the group UK Families Flight  and have written to ious ministers. We must be totally consistent in our responses.” A copy was sent to Mrs Thatcher. The Crown Office said the criminal probe into the disaster remained live, while the Foreign Office added: “We will not be commenting on the contents of our archive files.”   Only one person has been convicted over Lockerbie, Libyan Abdelbaset al-Megrahi, jailed for le in . Co-accused Lamen Khala Fhimah was acquitted. Al-Megrahi died in , aged , after being freed on compassionate grounds three years earlier. Dr Swire and a number of British victims’ families believe he may have been wrongly convicted. In , the Mirror revealed a security guard at Heathrow – where the New York-bound plane made a stop – discovered a break in at the Pan Am baggage area on the day of the attack. This was not revealed during the trial. Libya was suspected early in the probe as former leader Muammar Gaddafi is believed to have wanted revenge for the US bombing of Tripoli in .  But the finger of blame was also pointed at Iran. In July , a US Navy warship in the Persian Gulf shot down Iran Air Flight , killing  civilians, including  children. The Lockerbie Air Disaster Fund raised pound.million, of which nearly half was spent compensating victims and the rest went on projects in the town. Libya’s regime eventually accepted responsibility for the attack and agreed in  to pay pound.billion in compensation infor the lting of international sanctions.

title: meghan markle frustrates royal staff
story: NewsMeghan Markle frustrates royal staff and falls out with sister-in-law KateMany felt she would be the breath of fresh air the royals needed, but there is a feeling of frustration developingShareCommentsByRussell Myers:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video kate-middleton-speaks-meghan-over-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSix months after the Duchess of Sussex’s fairytale wedding, it appears the honeymoon could indeed be over. And while many felt she would be the breath of fresh air the royals needed, there is a certain feeling of frustration developing. With an unrelenting schedule and a perfectionist’s attitude, it is clear Meghan, , has thrown herself into royal le. But the constant ‘go-getter’ persona is wearing thin among some members of the household. Her attitude from the off was, ‘I want to know everything’. While that’s admirable, the whirlwind nature of it all is just not possible. There is so much to get to grips with. People feel she is putting too much pressure on herself and needs to realise there’s more to royal duty than learning the steps, making speeches.   “Some staff have even discussed how they can encourage her to slow down but, so far, it has been dficult.” Details of her unrelenting schedule have emerged, revealing apparent am texts, emails and even dawn calls to staff with ious demands. Then there is the row over an emerald tiara Meghan wanted to wear for her wedding and reports emerging of a rt with the Duchess of Cambridge. Another source added: “It’s obvious the two women are pretty dferent and while they haven’t been involved in a soap opera-style falling out, they aren’t exactly the best of friends.  “But their lack of closeness could also be to do with the two brothers wanting to pursue their own lives and there’s no real desire to be spending every waking minute together.” The Daily Mirror understands Meghan and Harry’s move to Frogmore Cottage at Windsor Castle was partly to do with William’s ambitions for Kensington Palace. However, one source suggests that after William and Kate opted to remain in the palace once Charles becomes King, they also decided they want to have -room Apartment  and turn it into an array of “state rooms”. A source said: “The plan would be to use the rooms for banquets and welcoming heads of states, and honoured guests. Harry and Meghan were offered other accommodation within the palace but saw this as the perfect opportunity to get out of London and start afresh.” Though both families will keep their offices at the palace, Meghan and Harry will face a -mile comshyshymute into London. The source added: “On the one hand it’s felt the breathing space will be a good thing for all involved. But on the other, those early-morning calls just might get a little earlier.”

title: mum given 6 months live
story: NewsMum given  months to live with  brain tumours is symptom-FREE after finding trial onlineBrave Heidi Spencer, who has two young sons, claims her brain tumours vanished within months of treatmentShareCommentsBySophie Evans:,  NOV NewsHeidi Spencer, pictured with her sons William, seven, and Lewis, four, now claims to be symptom-free "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum with cancer who was given as little as six months to live claims she is now symptom-free after finding a drug trial online. Heidi Spencer, who has two young sons, took to the Internet in a desperate bid to find treatment for her  brain tumours.The -year-old had reportedly been told the NHS could only offer her palliative chemotherapy for her Stage  lung cancer. But determined not to give up, she scoured the web and found a US test that pinpoints what drugs might work best for patients. And just months after undergoing the test and being given drugs to treat her cancer, she claims her brain tumours vanished. She says other tumours in her bones and lung are either in remission or have shrunk - and that her disease is now under control.   If I’d relied on NHS advice and their standard of care I would be dead now, Heidi, who works as a business analyst, told The Sun. She added: “I owe my le to those tests and to not always listening to the doctors.” The married mum, who lives in Cheshire, was diagnosed with Stage  cancer after her leg went numb on Mother’s Day last year. She was devastated to hear the disease had already spread.Doctors gave her between six and  months to live, but after going online, she came across an American test called FoundationOne.Fortunately, she managed to get the test - which typically costs pound, - for free through a trial at The Christie in Withington, Manchester.  It saw her genes examined to identy the ones driving her cancer. Following the test, Heidi discovered that five of her genes had mutated - two of which had available treatments, which she was given.She also underwent targeted radiotherapy, the newspaper reports. And the mum, who has sons William, seven, and Lewis, four, with her husband David, believes she now owes her le to the test.While she is not cured, her cancer is reportedly under control.Earlier this year, a fundraising page was set up for the brave mum to help pay for any drugs she might need in her cancer fight. A post on the JustGiving page says she is fighting to live.   She is also fighting to be there to raise her boys and fighting to push conventional medicine into accepting that she has a right to hope, be positive and search for the holy grail of cancer cures, it adds.According to the page, Heidi, from Burland, is a non-smoker who has had ious jobs - from a water engineer in Africa to an actor.She says shes determined to beat her miserable disease.Her consultant at The Christie warned they have to be reserved when delivering advice to patients because not everyone will benefit.

title: mum saved 50000 benefits payments
story: NewsMum who saved £k in benefits to enrich sons le convicted of fraudKayann Phillips, , was entitled to social security benefits but failed to declare her savings to the Department of Work and PensionsShareCommentsByLiz Day:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsKayann Phillips, , was found guilty of benefit fraud at Cardf Crown Court "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum who saved up pound, in benefit payments but failed to declare them has been convicted of fraud and told she may be forced to pay the money back. Kayann Phillips, a carer for her -year-old son, was absolutely entitled to claim social security benefits between August  and September , the court heard. After building up more than pound, in savings at one point she has now been convicted of benefit fraud, reports Wales Online. Phillips, , had failed to declare the savings when applying for benefits. Speaking atCardf Crown Court, Judge Jeremy Jenkins said: “I find that this is an unusual case.” In his sentencing remarks Judge Jenkins said: “Unusually you were not spending those benefits to the full extent but you were saving part of the money you received.   “You were saving, I have no doubt, for a very noble purpose – to enrich your son’s le.” The court heard her adult son has “considerable dficulties” and she has been caring for him since he was born. Benefit claimants must inform the Department for Work and Pensionsthey have savings. The authorities then make deductions according to the amount involved. Prosecutors said at one stage Phillips had more than pound, in savings but failed to declare them on her claim forms. Judge Jenkins said: “As a result you were not entitled to the full benefits you continued to receive.” Nuhu Gobir, prosecuting, said the total overpayment was more than pound, and there will be a hearing under the Proceeds of Crime Act on February . Clare Wilks, defending, described the circumstances as “unusual” and said the Probation Service found her client to present a low risk of re-offending. The court heard the defendant only has access to her current account as her other accounts have been restrained. Judge Jenkins said: “I find that this is an unusual case, albeit the charge of fraud is clearly made out.” He noted the amount involved as “considerable” and said the forms made it “abundantly clear” the defendant should have declared any savings. The judge described Phillips as a “dedicated” mother who had previously led an “unblemished” le. He added: “You are  and you have never before come anywhere close to getting into trouble.” Phillips, from Llanharan,Pontyclun, was given a -month prison sentence suspended for  months.

title: public schoolboy who became one
story: NewsPublic schoolboy who became one of worlds best poker players found deadElliott Blackburne, who had attended a ,-a-year public school growing up, had fallen on hard times, an inquest was toldShareCommentsByAshlie BlakeyChris kitching:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsThe investigation into Elliott Blackburnes death revealed no foul play, say police "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA former public schoolboy who became a top poker player died in squalor from a drug overdose after he ingested up to  times the lethal level of cocaine and heroin, an inquest heard. Elliott Blackburne, , is thought to have taken the drugs after he went back to friend George Booths flat to drink wine following a night out in a pub ahead of Christmas. The former boss of a digital marketing firm was found dead the following afternoon by Mr Booth, who was woken up by Mr Blackburnes mobile phone ringing. Mr Booth sent a message saying Its not good news in reply to an SOS group text from Mr Blackburnes girlfriend, who askedanyone knew where her boyfriend was. Mr Booth then messaged a friend in Hong Kong, saying: I cant believe what had happened to Elliott. Tests showed Mr Blackburne, a professional gambler who had previously made the top three in the  World Poker Championships, had  micrograms of heroin and cocaine per litre of blood.A level of mg can be fatal with a first time user and mg would be fatal for regular users of the drugs.   Police investigated after Mr Blackburnes family alleged the flat had been tidied to destroy evidence following the tragedy - but found no foul play. Mr Blackburne, from Altrincham, Greater Manchester, was described as a caring and compassionate son who had attended Hale Preparatory school and the pound,-a-year Cheadle Hulme School before enrolling at university. His mother, Colette Blackburne, , told the Stockport inquest: He was the le and soul of the party, no matter how dark things were hed always bounce back. He was just a good boy who got into the wrong place. He went to Hale Preparatory School and after his death his headmaster sent a beautul letter to us about the kind of student he was. He started to drink when he earned money and had a very addictive personality. He also had a problem with gambling, which initially he was a whiz at. He had huge successes with gambling at first, he was in the top three at the world poker championship. He got into debt around nine years ago and it continued until recently but to a much lesser degree. I did pay off a substantial amount of debts for it which I would say relieved the pressure. Elliott knew my views on drugs and I had a suspicion that he may have taken drugs in the past - but I would not associate him as someone to use stronger substances such as cocaine or heroin. He was socialising with old school friends, people he met in the pub - he always wanted to be a social butterfly. Recalling the tragedy on December , , she said: Elliots girlfriend Kirsty rang me and said I cant get hold of him, so she said shed arrange a group message. She got a text from someone at .pm so say its not good news. When I got there I found it very strange that the arm of the sofa was broken off, the flat was unusually clean and all clothes were packed up. It had obviously been cleaned for our benefit. The position of my son on the floor was prudent to having been dragged. The TV was in a cardboard box and there were four ski bags on the bag completely full. In my mind I feel he was going to go and say that Elliott was alive when he left and had gone to spend Christmas with his family. Who had supplied that amount of heroin to my son   In a statement, Mr Blackburnes partner, Kirsty Gallagher, said: We suspected that George had covered up what had happened. Since Elliotts death, George has given strange and inconsistent accounts of what happened. I believe George had given Elliott the drugs and had panicked and was going to leave Elliott in the flat. I believe George panicked and left Elliott for a while before he decided what to do, I believe his family had been called early in the day to help clean up the flat and cover up what had happened. I want to get the phone records of George and his family. We just want to know the truth.. Mr Booth, from Sale, denied witnessing Mr Blackburne take any drugs and claimed to have no knowledge about foil that was found under his bed. He told the hearing: I met him a few weeks before the incident, he was good friends with a friend of mine and we drank in the same pub. His mate asked methere was any chance he could get his head down in my spare room. It was the Saturday night on  December wed had a few drinks and gone back to the flat at about  or  oclock. We stayed up for a bit of a chit chat and stuff but I wanted to go to the match the next day. I saw him on the Tuesday on the evening time and he askedhe could get his head down at mine. I didnt want it to start developing into long-term - but we went back to the flat at about midnight again. We had a bottle of wine back at the flat. I heard him get up in the middle of the night for a water and then the next day, I woke up late afternoon and heard his phone going. Id not jumped up because I didnt know why he wouldnt want to answer his phone. I saw him on the bed in a funny position and I just knew. I touched him and he was cold as ice. He was clothed. I phoned up the paramedics immediately. They told me to get him on the floor and administer CPR, but he was a strong lad. I was in a state of total shock. I phoned up our friend and phoned my family up, before you know it there was a few people around. I think it was a tragic accident that happened. I tried my hardest for the lad and put him up.   He added: Id had parties before and I dont know who putthere. Im a party guy. Ive used substances in the past but it is irrelevant to whats happened here. Det Sgt Matthew Gregory said: Elliott was in the spare room on the floor but we did not find anything that concerned us on his body. We found a small snap bag, which from experience, controlled drugs are normally supplied in. That was empty other than trace remnants, that was found under the bed of George Booth. It may have been consistent to brown powder which may have been heroin. There was no foil found under the spare bed but there were pieces of foil that had burn marks on them - usually in the burning of heroin. I did not find any evidence of any third party involvement or suspicious circumstances. The bags with some clothing in struck me as being there for some time. I did not get the impression that the house was packed up - the flat being really clean was not particularly the impression I got, there was a bottle of wine on the side in the kitchen. Det Insp Terry Chatterton added: Mr Booth had sent a message to a male in Hong Kong saying that they had gone to bed and Elliott had fallen asleep on the sofa. He had been in WhatsApp contact with a friend in Hong Kong saying I cant believe what had happened to Elliott. I concluded that our investigation was very thorough and remain satisfied that there was no third party involvement or any suspicious circumstances in his death. Recording a conclusion of a drug-related death, coroner Chris Morris said: This is a tragic case with Mr Blackburne being a much-loved son who had many positive attributes. but I am satisfied that he was a user of elicit drugs. Mr Blackburne ed to Mr Booths flat in Sale to spent the night there as favour. Mr Booths account was that although alcohol was consumed, he neither took himself that night or did he witness Mr Blackburne taking any elicit drugs. I did not find him to be a wholly reliable witness, particularly with regards to whether any drugs were consumed. But there is no evidence to suggest the substances were forced upon Mr Blackburne.
